newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK democrats use balloons in lofty China protest.
newsitem.headline: HK democrats use balloons in lofty China protest.

text.p: Pro-democracy activists sent a banner attached to dozens of helium-filled balloons drifting in to China on Saturday to protest against Bejing-backed plans to change in the territory.
About a dozen members of the United Front Against the Provisional Legislature drove into the Lok Ma Chau border area to send off the balloons and banner.
The provisional legislature is the Beijing-annointed body which will replace Hong Kong's existing elected legislature when the territory reverts to Chinese rule in a few months.

The protestors cheered as the banner, which read: "Against the provisional legislature passing laws before July 1", floated towards the Chinese border city of Shenzhen where a meeting of the China-crafted provisional legislature is being held.
About a dozen policemen looked on but did not interfere as the group confined its protest within public areas.
Beijing will replace Hong Kong's present chamber with the interim legislature on July 1, when Britain hands the territory back to China after more than 150 years of colonial rule.
But Hong Kong's pro-democracy camp is virulently against the interim chamber and has vowed to sue it if it tried to pass laws before the handover.
Spokesman for the protestors, To Kwan Hang, said the group opted to release the balloons because many of his colleagues were not permitted to travel to China.
"The Chinese government is afraid of hearing Hong Kong voices. So we are doing this to bring our views over to them," To told reporters.

This is the second time the United Front has launched protests via balloons. Some members of the group were charged by police after they intruded into a restricted border area in December during a similar protest against the interim chamber.
